instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2879: What is 820-2879? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.D9701: What is D9701? diode in the backlight circuit sitting between the BKL_SW pin of the LED driver and backlight output. Very common for via between this and BKL_FB for feedback to blow, causing no boost. Measure continuity between pin 2 of this diode and feedback pin of LED driver if backlight output is PPBUS_G3H with no boost.
definitions.BKL_PWM: What is BKL_PWM? BKL_PWM sets the brightness of the screen. The system will send a PWM signal to BKL_PWM pin to set brightness. If this is low, backlight voltage will boost higher than PPBUS_G3H input, but not enough to make the screen light properly..
definitions.BKL_EN: What is BKL_EN? BKL_EN enables backlight. Anytime you see a signal ending with “_EN” , that means this signal being present/high enables what it is referring to. This signal says “BKL” before “_EN”. “BKL” sounds short for “BACKLIGHT”, so it is safe to assume this signal enables backlight when present. .
definitions.Q9706: What is Q9706? Q9706 takes PPBUS_G3H's vltage and sends it through to the backlight circuit. If Q9706 is not allowing PPBUS_G3H through, you will get no voltage on the backlight circuit. Q9706 is a P channel MOSFET, meaning power will flow through it when the voltage on the gate is lower than on the source. Look at pin 3. R9788 takes the 12.6v that is on the source and places it right on pin 3. This will set Q9706 to "off", and not allow it to pass power, as the voltage on the source and the gate are identical..
definitions.PLT_RST: What is PLT_RST?  PLT_RST stands for platform reset. .
definitions.3V3_S0: What is 3V3_S0? Abbreviation for PP3V3_S0, a 3.3v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message:
There are signs of liquid damage in the area between the lvds connector and the fan.
12.6 v at backlight fuse
I get image on screen

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
[SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
[SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message:
Even with <SIGNAL>BKL_EN</SIGNAL> missing there should be 12.6v going through the circuit. 

What voltage is on pin 4 of <TRANSISTOR>Q9706</TRANSISTOR>? Pin 3 of <TRANSISTOR>Q9706</TRANSISTOR>?

How do <RESISTOR>R9731</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R9715</RESISTOR> look?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message: <RESISTOR>R0910</RESISTOR> is also a common suspect. Did you measure on both sides of the fuse?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message:
[USER="1"]larossmann[/USER] I don't have <TRANSISTOR>Q9706</TRANSISTOR> on this board. But I suppose it is the same as <TRANSISTOR>Q9806</TRANSISTOR>.
Pin 3 12.22 volt
Pin 4 12.58 volt

I belive that means that it don't let power thru

<TRANSISTOR>Q9807</TRANSISTOR>
pin 5 3.3 volt
pin 2 0 volt


<RESISTOR>R9715</RESISTOR> , <RESISTOR>R9731</RESISTOR> looks good

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R0910</RESISTOR> is good.
Yes, I meassured on both sides of fuse.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message: This is weird cause that would mean <SIGNAL>PLT_RST</SIGNAL> is low. Check it somewhere else like <RESISTOR>R2891</RESISTOR> or 92. If also low check resistance to ground on there.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message: <RESISTOR>R2891</RESISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R2892</RESISTOR> looks good. 5.8 k resistance to groud and 0 volt on both

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message: is <CHIP>U1400</CHIP> bad or could it be something before it?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message: You can remove <RESISTOR>R2891</RESISTOR>/92/93/94/95 and see if <SIGNAL>PCIE_RESET_L</SIGNAL> comes high again. Could be crap under firewire chip if it is still low after removing all that. Last thing to pull would be firewire chip. If it is still low after that the MCP will be dead and that would be the end.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message:
i removed the five resistors but still get 0 volt
I accidently touched both pads where <RESISTOR>R2893</RESISTOR> was located with my probe that caused backlight to light up!

Is <CHIP>U4100</CHIP> firewire chip?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message:
<CHIP>U4100</CHIP> is FireWire can be removed without issue, well firewire won't work but who cares. Also remove <CHIP>U4290</CHIP> while you are doing that. If there is still no <SIGNAL>PLT_RST</SIGNAL> by then the MCP89 will probably be fried.
My bet is that MCP is  bad as with a little "pull up" from the multimeter it works.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message:
No luck.

Thanks for helping me with this one

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message: I found a note that i wrote a couple of months ago about this board and i just found it. Dont know if it matters but i meassured L2590 it should be 3.3 volt but it is 2.5 volt. is this power to the MCP?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message:
2.5V is fine, depends if <CHIP>U2592</CHIP> is fitted or not. This is a dead MCP not pulling up <SIGNAL>PLT_RST</SIGNAL>.
You could try to add a 100K pull up resistor to <SIGNAL>3V3_S0</SIGNAL> to <SIGNAL>PLT_RST</SIGNAL>, but no idea if stuff wil properly initialize like that.
